revision.comment: /* History */clean up; http→https for [[Google Books]] and other Google services using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Commandaria''' (also called '''Commanderia''' and '''Coumadarka'''; {{lang-el|κουμανδαρία}}, {{lang|el|κουμανταρία}} and {{lang-el|κουμανταρκά}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Κουμανταρκά (κουμανδαρία)|url=http://foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy/web/guest/trofima/civitem/1159#_bs_civitems_tabcyprus.tab1|website=foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy|publisher=Cyprus Food Virtual Museum|accessdate=26 November 2015|language=Greek}}</ref>) is an amber-coloured sweet [[dessert wine]] made in the Commandaria region of [[Cyprus]] on the foothills of the [[Troödos Mountains|Troödos mountains]]. Commandaria is made from sun-dried grapes of the varieties [[Xynisteri]] and [[Mavro]]. While often a [[fortified wine]], through its production method it often reaches high alcohol levels, around 15%, already before fortification. It represents an ancient wine style documented in Cyprus back to 800 BC and has the distinction of being the world's oldest named wine still in production, with the name Commandaria dating back to the [[crusades]] in the 12th century.
== History == The wine has a rich history, said to date back to the time of the [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]], where it was a popular drink at [[festival]]s. A dried grape wine from Cyprus was first known to be described in 800 BC by the Greek poet [[Hesiod]] and was known, by much later, as the ''Cypriot Manna''.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Quality of Foods and Beverages: Chemistry and Technology | others = ed. George E. Inglett & George Charalambous | publisher = Academic Press Inc. | year = 1981 | isbn = 0-12-169101-2 | author = ed. by George Charalambous ...}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Michele |last=Kambas |title=Cypriots thought to be first Mediterranean winemakers |date=2005-05-21 |publisher=Reuters |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/news/content.asp?aid=56560 |work=Kathimerini |pages= |accessdate=2007-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120005508/http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/news/content.asp?aid=56560 |archivedate=November 20, 2007 }}</ref>
[[File:Commandaria bottle.jpg|thumb|right|Commandaria by KEO]]
During the crusades, Commandaria was served at the 12th century wedding of King [[Richard I of England|Richard the Lionheart]] to [[Berengaria of Navarre]], in the town of [[Limassol]]; it was during the wedding that King Richard pronounced Commandaria "the wine of kings and the king of wines".<ref name='Reuters 1'>{{cite news | first=Sarah | last=Ktisti |authorlink= | title=Ancient Cypriot wine enters vintage major league | date=Aug 11, 2009 | publisher=[[Reuters]] | url =http://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSTRE57A2PA20090811 | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-08-12 }}</ref> Near the end of the century he sold the island to the [[Knights Templar]], who then sold it to [[Guy de Lusignan]], but kept a large feudal estate at [[Kolossi]], close to Limassol, to themselves. This estate was referred to as ''"La Grande Commanderie"''. The word ''[[Commandry (feudalism)|Commanderie]]'' referred to the [[Kolossi Castle|military headquarters]] whilst ''Grande'' helped distinguish it from two smaller such command posts on the island, one close to [[Paphos]] (Phoenix) and another near [[Kyrenia]] (Templos). This area under the control of the Knights Templar (and subsequently the [[Knights Hospitaller]]) became known as ''Commandaria''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/books/pdf/The_Edinburgh_encyclopaedia__conducted_b.pdf?vid=0Gc3bIjIGir1lkJQ&id=7QmtyiHKwLYC&output=pdf&sig=65H5mJ5pkgtTqXBGO-CTVtZMfYk |title=The Edinburgh encyclopaedia (Volume VII, page 538) |last=Brewster |first=D. |year=1830 |format=PDF |publisher=William Blackwood }}</ref> When the knights began producing large quantities of the wine for export to Europe's royal courts and for supplying pilgrims en route to the holy lands, the wine assumed the name of the region. Thus it has the distinction of being the world's oldest named wine still in production.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-11000/oldest-manufactured-wine/ | title = The Oldest Manufactured Wine | accessdate = 2014-01-04 | publisher = [[Guinness World Records]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=David | last=Levin | title=The Wines of Aphrodite's Isle |date=November 2000 | publisher=Wine Communications Group | url =http://www.winebusiness.com/html/PrinterVersion.cfm?dataId=3582 | work =Wine Business Monthly | pages = | accessdate = 2007-04-02 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Jill | last=Campbell Mackay | title=On the wine trail with Jill Campbell Mackay | date= March 5, 2006 | publisher= | url =http://www.cyprus-mail.com/living/wine-trail-jill-campbell-mackay-0 | work =[[Cyprus Mail]] | pages = | accessdate = 2007-04-02 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Although today it is produced and marketed under the name ''Commandaria'', it has been referred to with several similar names and spellings in the past. In 1863, Thomas George Shaw in his book ''Wine, the vine, and the cellar'' refers to this wine as ''Commanderi''<ref>{{cite news | first=Thomas George | last=Shaw | title=Wine, the vine, and the cellar | year=1863 | publisher=Longman | url =https://www.google.com/books?vid=OCLC08949299&id=soIBAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA6-PA314&lpg=RA6-PA314&dq=cyprus+wine&as_brr=1#PPP14,M1 | work = | pages =315 | accessdate = 2007-02-20 }}</ref> whilst in 1879, [[Samuel Baker]] refers to it as ''Commanderia''.<ref name="gutenberg.org">{{cite book | author = Samuel W. Baker | title = Cyprus, as I Saw it in 1879 | page = 120 | year = 1879 | publisher = Project Gutenberg (Etext edition, 2003) | url = http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/3656}}</ref> In 1833 Cyrus Redding in his book "''A history and description of modern wines''" makes reference to the wine of the "''Commandery''".<ref>{{cite news | first=Cyrus | last=Redding | title=A history and description of modern wines | year=1833 | publisher=Whittaker Treacher & Arnot | url =https://www.google.com/books?vid=OCLC06498122&id=S8QqcnF48cgC&pg=RA12-PA265&lpg=RA12-PA265&dq=cyprus+wine+Cyrus+Redding&as_brr=1#PRA12-PA263,M1 | work = | pages =263 | accessdate = 2007-02-20 }}</ref>
Legend has it that in the 13th century [[Philip II of France|Philip Augustus of France]] held the first ever wine tasting competition. The event, branded The [[Battle of the Wines]] ''(fr. La Bataille des Vins)'', was recorded in a notable French poem written by [[Henry d'Andeli]] in 1224.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/La_Bataille_des_vins |title=La Bataille des Vins |accessdate=2007-04-03 |last=Henri |first=d'Andeli |at=verse 15 |year=1224 |language=French }}</ref> The competition which included wines from all over Europe and France, was won by a sweet wine from Cyprus widely believed to be Commandaria.<ref>{{cite web | title = Wine, the Last 1,000 Years | work = [[h2g2]] | publisher = BBC | date = May 21, 2002 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A734915}}</ref> The ''Commandery'' region itself fell into the control of his descendant [[Philip IV of France|Philip IV]] in 1307, after the [[Knights Templar#Arrests, charges, and dissolution|suppression of the Knights Templar]].
Another legend has it that the Ottoman sultan [[Selim II]] invaded the island just to acquire Commandaria; also that the grapes used to make this wine were the same grapes exported to Portugal that eventually became famous as the source of [[port wine]].<ref>{{cite news | first=Victorino | last=Matus | title=Selling Cyprus | date=2002-04-24 | publisher=News Corporation | url =http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/001/167sdyzx.asp | work =The Daily Standard | pages = | accessdate = 2007-08-10 }}</ref>
== Production == [[File:Mavro.jpg|thumb||right|150px|Mavro grapes used in the production of Commandaria.]]
Commandaria is made exclusively from two types of indigenous Cyprus grapes: [[Xynisteri]] and [[Mavro]].<ref name=a>{{cite web|last1=Mastropavlos|first1=Nikos|title=Οι δρόμοι του κρασιού στη Μεγαλόνησο|url=http://www.tovima.gr/vimagazino/views/article/?aid=576353|website=tovima.gr|publisher=To Vima|accessdate=24 November 2015|language=Greek}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Stephen | last = Meuse | title = Winemaking in transition | date = June 6, 2010 | url = http://www.boston.com/travel/getaways/europe/articles/2010/06/06/winemaking_in_transition/?page=2 | work = [[The Boston Globe]] | pages = 2 | accessdate = 2010-06-07}}</ref> The grapes are left to [[overripe on the vine]] and when sugar content reaches acceptable levels (corresponding to high [[must weight]]) they are harvested. More specifically, Xynisteri is picked when at around 12 [[Degree Baumé|degrees Baumé]] (°Bé) and Mavro at 15-16 °Bé. The grapes are then laid out in the sun to further increase the sugar density through evaporation. When the must weight reaches 19 to 23 °Bé the juice is extracted thorough crushing and pressing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.loel.com.cy/wine/liqueur_wine/commandaria_alasia.php |title=Commandaria Production Details |accessdate=2007-01-27 |work=LOEL website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307071217/http://www.loel.com.cy/wine/liqueur_wine/commandaria_alasia.php |archivedate=March 7, 2007 }}</ref> Fermentation takes place in reservoirs and will arrest naturally due to the high levels of alcohol achieved at around 15%. The above process has to take place within the confines of 14 designated villages that lie in the Commandaria Region ''(see below)''. Commandaria, by law is aged for at least four years in Oak Barrels but this can take place outside the above designated area within Cyprus under strict control and under the conditions laid down in Cypriot legislation.<ref name='Council Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 Annex VI Part D (1)(b)'> {{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/agriculture/markets/wine/studies/wine.pdf |title=Negotiation results on Wine (page 6 negotiation position No 29) |accessdate=2007-03-30 |format=PDF |publisher=European Commission }}</ref>
Once fermentation has been completed, at a minimum alcohol level of 10% (which is often exceeded), the alcoholic strength of Commandaria may be increased by the addition of pure 95% grape alcohol or a wine distillate of at least 70% alcohol. However, after this addition, the wine's actual alcohol content may not exceed 20%, while its total [[potential alcohol]] (including its sugar content) must be at least 22.5%.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |editor=[[Jancis Robinson]] | encyclopedia=[[Oxford Companion to Wine]] |edition= Third |title=Commandaria |year=2006 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=0-19-860990-6 |pages=190 }}</ref> Thus, Commandaria may be a fortified wine, but fortification is not mandatory.
[[File:Xynisteri 1.jpg|thumb||left|150px|[[Xynisteri]] grapes.]]
The origins of the production method are not definite. In his poem ''[[Works and Days]]'', written in the 7th century BC, [[Hesiod]], writes: {{cquote|Forget not next the ripen'd Grapes to lay, Ten Nights in Air, nor take them in by Day; Five more remember, e're the Wine is made, To let them ly, to mellow in the Shade; And in the sixth briskly yourself employ, To cask the Gift of Bacchus, Sire of Joy."<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Works and Days, Book 2 |title=English Translations: From Ancient and Modern Poems |volume=2 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mHNHAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA751 |page=751 |last=[[Hesiod]] |others=Thomas Cooke (trans.) |date=1810 |publisher=N. Blandford}}</ref>}}
[[Pliny the Elder]] describes similar methods employed by the Greeks for making a sweet wines, {{cquote|The grapes are left on the vine to dry in the sun...It is made by drying grapes in the sun, and then placing them for seven days in a closed place upon hurdles, some seven Feet from the ground, care being taken to protect them at night from the dews: on the eighth day they are trodden out: this method, it is said, produces a liquor of exquisite bouquet and flavour. The liquor known as melitites is also one of the sweet wines <ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0137%3Abook%3D14%3Achapter%3D11| Pliny the Elder, on Perseus]</ref>}}
In his account Samuel Baker describes the production in 1879 {{cquote|...the commanderia grapes are collected and spread upon the flat mud-plastered roofs of the native houses, and are exposed for several days, until they show symptoms of shriveling in the skin, and the stalks have partially dried: they are then [[pressed (wine)|pressed]]……"}} Interestingly he claims that the evolution of this method was more out of necessity than choice..… {{cquote|"It has been imagined by some travellers that the grapes are purposely dried before pressing; on the other hand, I have been assured by the inhabitants that their only reason for heaping and exposing their crop upon the house-tops is the danger of leaving it to ripen in the vineyard. None of the plots are fenced, and before the grapes are sufficiently ripe for pressing they are stolen in large quantities, or destroyed by cattle, goats, mules, and every stray animal that is attracted to the fields…."<ref>{{cite book |author=Samuel White Baker, |title=Cyprus As I Saw It in 1879 |publisher= |location= |isbn=1-84637-912-1 |oclc= |doi=}}</ref>}}
Commandaria is produced both by the large wine industries ([[KEO Ltd|KEO]], ETKO, LOEL and SODAP) and by small local producers of the Commandaria appellation zone ''(see below)''.
Data recorded by [[Samuel Baker]] in his book ''Cyprus - How I saw it in 1879'' reveal that in the late 19th century Cyprus had an annual production of about 300,000 [[Oka (measure)|okes]], equivalent to about 385,000 litres (data reflects only duty-paid production). Of this, Cyprus exported 180,103 okes from [[Limassol Port]], of which the vast majority went to [[Austria]] (155,000 okes valued at UK£2,075).<ref name="gutenberg.org"/>
Official figures released by Cyprus’ Vines Products Commission show that there is a general increasing trend in the volumes produced. Much of Commandaria production is still targeted for export.<ref>{{cite news | first=Yiannis | last=Ioannou | title=Επιστροφή στην κουμανδαρία (Return to Commandaria) | date=2006-05-08 | publisher= | url =http://www.simerini.com/nqcontent.cfm?a_id=250845 | work =[[Simerini]] | pages = | accessdate = 2007-06-20 | language = Greek }}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year | 1878 | 1879 | 2001 | 2002 | 2003 | 2004 | 2005 |- ! Total Production {{nobold|''(in kilograms of grapes processed)''}} | 150,000<ref>Note: converted from figures given in [[Oka (measure)|okes]] (from Samuel Baker reference)</ref> | 385,000<ref name="Non taxed note">Note: does not include non taxed production, converted from figures given in [[Oka (measure)|okes]] (from Samuel Baker reference)</ref> | 253,495 | 155,925 | 209,250 | 564,179 | 449,290 |- ! Total Exports {{nobold|''(in litres)''}} | 200,000<ref name="Non taxed note"/> | | 228,369 | 210,953 | 189,384 | 189,236 | 82,728 |}
== Authentication == [[File:Cyprus Commandaria Region.png|thumb|300px|Map of SW Cyprus outlining the Commandaria region]] Currently Commandaria holds a [[protected designation of origin]] (PDO) within the [[European Union]],<ref>{{cite journal|title=COMMISSION REGULATION (EC) No 1429/2004|journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=2004-08-09|first=|last=|volume=|issue=|pages= |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/pri/en/oj/dat/2004/l_263/l_26320040810en00110020.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> the [[United States]]<ref>{{cite journal|title=Agreement between the European Community and the United States of America on trade in wine|journal=Official journal of the European Union |date=2006-03-24|first=|last=|volume=|issue=|pages= |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/l_087/l_08720060324en00020074.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-01-25}}</ref> and [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Trademarks Act |journal=Canada Gazette Part I |date=2004-11-12 |volume=138 |issue=50 |pages=3639 |url=http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p1/2004/2004-12-11/pdf/g1-13850.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306221857/http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p1/2004/2004-12-11/pdf/g1-13850.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }}</ref><ref name='Cyprus Mail 2004-04-16'>{{cite news | first=Katya | last=Diogenous | title=Official patent for Commandaria | date=2004-04-16 | publisher= | url =http://www.cyprus-mail.com/commandaria/official-patent-commandaria | work =[[Cyprus Mail]] | pages = | accessdate = 2007-01-27 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> By Cypriot legislation passed on March 2, 1990, it is only produced in a collection of 14 neighbouring villages: [[Agios Georgios, Limassol|Agios Georgios]], [[Agios Konstantinos, Cyprus|Agios Konstantinos]], [[Agios Mamas]], [[Agios Pavlos, Limassol|Agios Pavlos]], [[Apsiou]], [[Gerasa, Cyprus|Gerasa]], [[Doros, Cyprus|Doros]], [[Zoopigi]], [[Kalo Chorio, Limassol|Kalo Chorio]], [[Kapilio]], [[Laneia]], [[Louvaras]], [[Monagri]] and [[Silikou]]. The designated area has assumed the name of the Commandaria Region and is located on the south facing slopes of the [[Troödos Mountains]] at an altitude of 500-900m within the [[Limassol District]]. Only grapes from vineyards that have been planted for at least 4 years are allowed. [[Vine training]] must follow the goblet method and watering is prohibited. The grape harvest may only commence after the vine products commission of Cyprus has given the green light, based on the average sugar content of the grapes. Xinisteri grapes must demonstrate a sugar content of 212 g/L whilst Mavro can only qualify with a reading of 258 g/L and above. The sugar concentration is then raised by laying the grapes in the sun, usually for 7–10 days, to a strict window of 390 to 450g/L.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Από τον Ριχάρδο στην Ονομασία Προέλευσης (From Richard the Lionheart to DOC) | date=2004-03-08 | publisher= | url =http://www.politis-news.com/cgibin/hweb?-A=644&-V=fakeloiarticles | work =[[Politis (Cyprus)|Politis Newspaper]] | pages = | accessdate = 2007-03-30 | language = Greek }}</ref>
In February 2006, the Wine Products Association of Cyprus selected an official Commandaria wine glass, manufactured by [[Riedel]], an Austrian wine glass company.<ref>{{cite news|title=Old wine in a new glass |work=[[Cyprus Mail]] |date=March 26, 2006 |url=http://www.cyprus-mail.com/news/main.php?id=25060&archive=1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070101081935/http://www.cyprus-mail.com:80/news/main.php?id=25060&archive=1 |archivedate=2007-01-01 |df= }}</ref>
